title: مُرَاجَعَةٌ
explanation: Review of key grammatical concepts from Book 1 including demonstratives (هَذَا/هَذِهِ), question particles (مَا/مَنْ/أَيْنَ), possession (الإِضَافَة), prepositions, and basic verb conjugations.

title: الضَّمَائِرُ الْمُتَّصِلَةُ (الْمَفْعُول)
explanation: Object pronouns attach directly to verbs. They include: ـهُ (him), ـهَا (her), ـهُمْ (them m.), ـهُنَّ (them f.), ـكَ (you m.), ـكِ (you f.), ـكُمْ (you pl.), ـنِي (me), ـنَا (us).

title: الاسْمُ الْمَوْصُول
explanation: Relative pronouns connect a noun to a descriptive clause. الَّذِي (who/which, m. sing.), الَّتِي (who/which, f. sing.), الَّذِينَ (who/which, m. pl.), اللَّاتِي/اللَّوَاتِي (who/which, f. pl.).

title: أَسْمَاءُ الإِشَارَةِ لِلْجَمْع
explanation: هَؤُلَاءِ means 'these' for both masculine and feminine plurals referring to people. أُولَئِكَ means 'those' for both masculine and feminine plurals referring to people.

title: فِعْلُ الأَمْر
explanation: The imperative is formed from the present tense by removing the prefix and adding a hamzat al-wasl if needed. اُكْتُبْ (write!), اِقْرَأْ (read!), اِذْهَبْ (go!). For feminine: اُكْتُبِي, اِقْرَئِي, اِذْهَبِي.

title: النَّهْي
explanation: Prohibition is formed using لَا + the jussive (مَجْزُوم) form of the present tense verb. لَا تَكْتُبْ (don't write), لَا تَقْرَأْ (don't read), لَا تَذْهَبْ (don't go).

title: اسْمُ الْفَاعِل
explanation: The active participle describes the doer of an action. For Form I verbs, the pattern is فَاعِل: كَاتِب (writer), قَارِئ (reader), جَالِس (sitting). It functions as an adjective or noun.

title: اسْمُ الْمَفْعُول
explanation: The passive participle describes what receives the action. For Form I verbs, the pattern is مَفْعُول: مَكْتُوب (written), مَفْتُوح (opened), مَعْرُوف (known).

title: الْمَصْدَر
explanation: The verbal noun (masdar) expresses the abstract meaning of a verb. Common patterns for Form I include فَعْل (كَتْب - writing), فِعَالَة (قِرَاءَة - reading), فُعُول (دُخُول - entering).

title: اسْمُ التَّفْضِيل
explanation: The comparative/superlative is formed on the pattern أَفْعَل: أَكْبَر (bigger/biggest), أَصْغَر (smaller/smallest), أَحْسَن (better/best). With مِنْ it's comparative; with الـ or إِضَافَة it's superlative.

title: الْمَبْنِيُّ لِلْمَجْهُول
explanation: The passive voice is formed by changing vowel patterns. Past passive: فُعِلَ (كُتِبَ - was written). Present passive: يُفْعَلُ (يُكْتَبُ - is being written). The subject becomes نَائِب الْفَاعِل.

title: الْفِعْلُ الْمُضَارِعُ الْمَنْصُوب
explanation: The subjunctive (مَنْصُوب) is used after أَنْ, لَنْ, كَيْ, لِـ. The final ضَمَّة changes to فَتْحَة: يَكْتُبَ, يَذْهَبَ. With لَنْ it negates the future.

title: الْفِعْلُ الْمُضَارِعُ الْمَجْزُوم
explanation: The jussive (مَجْزُوم) is used after لَمْ (didn't), لَا النَّاهِيَة (don't), لِـ الأَمْر (let), and conditional particles. The ending becomes sukun: لَمْ يَكْتُبْ, لَمْ يَذْهَبْ.

title: الْجُمْلَةُ الشَّرْطِيَّة
explanation: Conditional sentences use إِنْ or إِذَا for 'if'. إِنْ is for uncertain conditions, إِذَا for likely conditions. Both are followed by jussive or past tense verbs.

examples.english: If you study, you will succeed

title: الاسْتِثْنَاء
explanation: Exception uses إِلَّا (except), غَيْر (other than), or سِوَى (except). After إِلَّا in a complete affirmative sentence, the excepted noun takes نَصْب. In negative sentences, it may follow the case of the noun before إِلَّا.

title: الْعَدَد وَالْمَعْدُود (11-99)
explanation: Numbers 11-12 agree with the counted noun in gender. Numbers 13-19 show inverse gender agreement in the first part. Numbers 20-99 have the counted noun singular and accusative (تَمْيِيز).

title: ظَرْفُ الزَّمَانِ وَالْمَكَان
explanation: Adverbs of time (ظَرْف الزَّمَان): قَبْلَ (before), بَعْدَ (after), الْآنَ (now). Adverbs of place (ظَرْف الْمَكَان): فَوْقَ (above), تَحْتَ (under), أَمَامَ (in front), وَرَاءَ (behind). They take فَتْحَة as they are مَنْصُوب.

examples.english: He sat in front of the house
The book is on the table

title: الْحَال
explanation: الْحَال describes the state of the subject or object when the action occurs. It is indefinite (نَكِرَة), accusative (مَنْصُوب), and answers 'how?' or 'in what state?'. Often an active participle.

title: الفِعْل المَهْمُوز
explanation: Hamzated verbs have hamza (ء) as one of their root letters. They can have hamza at the beginning (أَخَذَ), middle (سَأَلَ), or end (قَرَأَ). Their conjugation generally follows regular verb patterns, but hamza may undergo spelling changes.

title: الفِعْل المُضَعَّف
explanation: Doubled verbs (الفِعْل المُضَعَّف) have identical second and third root letters (like مَدَّ from م-د-د). The two identical letters merge with a shadda. In certain conjugations, they may separate: مَدَدْتُ (I extended).

title: الفِعْل المِثَال
explanation: Assimilated verbs (الفِعْل المِثَال) have waw (و) or ya (ي) as their first root letter. In the present tense, the waw often drops: وَعَدَ → يَعِدُ (he promises), وَجَدَ → يَجِدُ (he finds).

title: الفِعْل الأَجْوَف
explanation: Hollow verbs (الفِعْل الأَجْوَف) have waw or ya as their middle root letter. The middle vowel changes: قَالَ (root ق-و-ل) becomes يَقُولُ in present, قُلْتُ in past 1st person. Examples: زَارَ → يَزُورُ, نَامَ → يَنَامُ.

title: جَمْع المُذَكَّر السَّالِم
explanation: Sound masculine plural is formed by adding ـُونَ (nominative) or ـِينَ (accusative/genitive) to nouns referring to male rational beings. مُعَلِّمُونَ (teachers, nom.), مُعَلِّمِينَ (teachers, acc./gen.). Used with numbers 20-90.

title: الفِعْل النَّاقِص
explanation: Defective verbs (الفِعْل النَّاقِص) have waw or ya as their final root letter. The final letter often changes or drops: دَعَا → يَدْعُو, رَمَى → يَرْمِي, مَشَى → يَمْشِي. In the past with attached pronouns: دَعَوْتُ.

title: الفِعْل اللَّفِيف
explanation: Doubly weak verbs (الفِعْل اللَّفِيف) have two weak letters in their root. They can be: لَفِيف مَفْرُوق (separated: وَقَى و-ق-ي) or لَفِيف مَقْرُون (adjacent: رَوَى ر-و-ي, طَوَى ط-و-ي).

title: اسْم التَّصْغِير
explanation: Diminutive nouns express smallness or endearment. Common patterns: فُعَيْل (كِتَاب → كُتَيِّب booklet), فُعَيْعِل (عُصْفُور → عُصَيْفِير little bird). They can indicate small size, youth, or affection.

title: البَاب السَّابِع (اِنْفَعَلَ)
explanation: Form VII verbs follow the pattern اِنْفَعَلَ - يَنْفَعِلُ. They typically express reflexive or passive meaning from Form I verbs. فَتَحَ (he opened) → اِنْفَتَحَ (it was opened), كَسَرَ (he broke) → اِنْكَسَرَ (it broke).

title: الأَفْعَال الضَّعِيفَة فِي السِّيَاق
explanation: Weak verbs appear frequently in religious and classical texts. Recognizing their patterns is essential for Quranic and hadith study. Common examples: قَالَ (hollow), دَعَا (defective), هَدَى (defective), رَضِيَ (defective).

examples.english: May Allah be pleased with him

title: البَاب الثَّامِن (اِفْتَعَلَ)
explanation: Form VIII verbs follow the pattern اِفْتَعَلَ - يَفْتَعِلُ. They often express reflexive meaning or effort. جَمَعَ (he gathered) → اِجْتَمَعَ (they gathered/met), سَمِعَ (he heard) → اِسْتَمَعَ (he listened carefully).

title: البَاب التَّاسِع (اِفْعَلَّ)
explanation: Form IX verbs follow the pattern اِفْعَلَّ - يَفْعَلُّ. This form is used almost exclusively for colors and physical defects. أَحْمَر (red) → اِحْمَرَّ (became red), أَصْفَر (yellow) → اِصْفَرَّ (became yellow).

title: البَاب العَاشِر (اِسْتَفْعَلَ)
explanation: Form X verbs follow the pattern اِسْتَفْعَلَ - يَسْتَفْعِلُ. They typically express seeking, requesting, or considering something. غَفَرَ (he forgave) → اِسْتَغْفَرَ (he sought forgiveness), أَذِنَ (he permitted) → اِسْتَأْذَنَ (he asked permission).

title: المَصَادِر لِجَمِيع الأَوْزَان
explanation: Each verb form has specific masdar patterns. Form II: تَفْعِيل, Form III: مُفَاعَلَة/فِعَال, Form IV: إِفْعَال, Form V: تَفَعُّل, Form VI: تَفَاعُل, Form VII: اِنْفِعَال, Form VIII: اِفْتِعَال, Form X: اِسْتِفْعَال.

examples.english: seeking forgiveness - he sought forgiveness (Form X)

title: اسْم الزَّمَان وَالْمَكَان
explanation: Nouns of time and place indicate where or when an action occurs. For Form I verbs, the pattern is مَفْعَل or مَفْعِل: مَكْتَب (office/place of writing), مَدْرَسَة (school), مَطْبَخ (kitchen). Derived forms use م + present stem.

examples.english: The food is in the kitchen

title: اسْم الآلَة
explanation: Nouns of instrument indicate the tool used to perform an action. Common patterns: مِفْعَل (مِفْتَاح - key), مِفْعَلَة (مِكْنَسَة - broom), مِفْعَال (مِنْشَار - saw). Modern words often use فَعَّالَة (ثَلَّاجَة - refrigerator).

examples.english: He opened the door with the key
The broom is in the room

title: الْمُثَنَّى
explanation: The dual indicates exactly two of something. It adds ـَانِ (nominative) or ـَيْنِ (accusative/genitive) to the singular. Verbs agree with dual subjects: الطَّالِبَانِ ذَهَبَا (the two students went).

title: جَمْع الْمُؤَنَّث السَّالِم
explanation: Sound feminine plural is formed by adding ـَاتٌ to nouns. Works for feminine nouns ending in ة: طَالِبَة → طَالِبَاتٌ, and some masculine/inanimate nouns. The accusative and genitive share the form ـَاتٍ.

title: جَمْع التَّكْسِير
explanation: Broken plurals change the internal pattern of the singular. Common patterns: أَفْعَال (قَلَم/أَقْلَام), فُعُول (بَيْت/بُيُوت), فِعَال (كِتَاب/كُتُب). These must be memorized as they're unpredictable.

title: الْمَمْنُوع مِنَ الصَّرْف
explanation: Certain nouns don't take tanween and use fatha instead of kasra for genitive. Categories: proper names (أَحْمَدُ), colors (أَحْمَرُ), comparative/superlative (أَكْبَرُ), patterns like مَفَاعِل (مَسَاجِد).

title: الْمُبْتَدَأ وَالْخَبَر
titleEn: Subject and Predicate in Nominal Sentences
explanation: Nominal sentences begin with a noun (مُبْتَدَأ) followed by a predicate (خَبَر). Both are nominative in basic form. The predicate can be a noun, adjective, prepositional phrase, or sentence.

examples.english: The book is on the table (prep. predicate)
Muhammad - his father is a doctor (sentence predicate)

title: تَقْدِيم الْخَبَر
explanation: The predicate normally follows the subject, but can be fronted for emphasis or necessity. Mandatory when predicate is a question word or when subject is indefinite with prepositional predicate: عِنْدِي كِتَابٌ.

examples.english: In the house is a man

title: الْفِعْل اللَّازِم وَالْمُتَعَدِّي
explanation: Intransitive verbs (لَازِم) don't take a direct object: ذَهَبَ (went), جَلَسَ (sat). Transitive verbs (مُتَعَدٍّ) take one or more objects: كَتَبَ الدَّرْسَ, أَعْطَى الطَّالِبَ كِتَابًا.

title: الْمَفْعُول بِهِ
explanation: The direct object (الْمَفْعُول بِهِ) receives the action of transitive verbs. It is always in the accusative case (مَنْصُوب). With attached pronouns: رَأَيْتُهُ (I saw him).

title: اسْمُ الْمَرَّة
explanation: The noun of single instance (اسم المرة) indicates that an action occurred once. For Form I verbs, the pattern is فَعْلَة: ضَرْبَة (one strike), جَلْسَة (one sitting), نَظْرَة (one glance).

examples.english: We sat for one long session

title: اسْمُ الْمَرَّة لِلأَفْعَال الْمَزِيدَة
titleEn: Noun of Single Instance for Derived Forms
explanation: For derived verb forms (II-X), add ة to the masdar to form the noun of single instance. If the masdar already ends in ة, add وَاحِدَة for clarification.

examples.english: He taught him one useful lesson

title: اسْمُ الْهَيْئَة
explanation: The noun of manner (اسم الهيئة) describes how an action is performed. For Form I verbs, the pattern is فِعْلَة: جِلْسَة (manner of sitting), مِشْيَة (manner of walking).

examples.english: He sat in the manner of a scholar
She walked the walk of an arrogant person

title: الْفَرْق بَيْنَ اسْم الْمَرَّة وَاسْم الْهَيْئَة
titleEn: Difference Between Noun of Instance and Manner
explanation: اسم المرة (فَعْلَة with fatha) indicates ONE occurrence. اسم الهيئة (فِعْلَة with kasra) describes HOW the action was performed. Note the kasra vs fatha on the first letter.

examples.english: one hit vs manner of hitting

title: مُرَاجَعَة: الأَوْزَان الْمُشْتَقَّة
explanation: Book 2 covered derived patterns: اسم الفاعل (فَاعِل), اسم المفعول (مَفْعُول), اسم الزمان والمكان (مَفْعَل), and اسم الآلة (مِفْعَل/مِفْعَلَة/مِفْعَال).

title: مُرَاجَعَة: أَنْوَاع الأَفْعَال
explanation: Book 2 covered various verb types: الصحيح (sound), المهموز (hamzated), الأجوف (hollow), الناقص (defective), and المضعف (doubled).

title: الصِّفَة الْمُشَبَّهَة - تَعْرِيف
explanation: الصفة المشبهة is derived from intransitive verbs and indicates a permanent quality. Unlike اسم الفاعل (temporary), it describes inherent, lasting characteristics like كَرِيم (generous) and حَسَن (good).

examples.english: The boy is good in character

title: الصِّفَة الْمُشَبَّهَة - الأَوْزَان
explanation: Common patterns: فَعِيل (كَرِيم), فَعِل (حَسَن), فَعْلَان (عَطْشَان), and أَفْعَل (أَحْمَر). Each pattern often describes a particular category of qualities.

title: الصِّفَة الْمُشَبَّهَة vs اسْم الْفَاعِل
explanation: اسم الفاعل indicates temporary action (ضَارِب - hitting now), while الصفة المشبهة indicates permanent quality (كَرِيم - inherently generous). The distinction is about duration.

title: الصِّفَة الْمُشَبَّهَة - السُّلُوك النَّحْوِيّ
explanation: الصفة المشبهة can govern a noun in genitive case, showing what the quality relates to. Example: حَسَنُ الْوَجْهِ (beautiful of face), طَيِّبُ الْقَلْبِ (good-hearted).

examples.english: The woman is old (big of age)

title: النِّسْبَة - تَعْرِيف
explanation: النسبة forms relative adjectives by adding يّ to nouns to show attribution. For example: مِصْر → مِصْرِيّ (Egyptian), إِسْلَام → إِسْلَامِيّ (Islamic). Feminine adds ـة.

title: النِّسْبَة - قَوَاعِد التَّكْوِين
explanation: When the noun ends in ة, drop it before adding يّ: مَكَّة → مَكِّيّ. The kasra before يّ is standard. For cities: المَدِينَة → مَدَنِيّ.

title: النِّسْبَة - الْكَلِمَات الْمُنْتَهِيَة بِالْيَاء
titleEn: Relative Adjectives - Words Ending in Ya
explanation: Words ending in ي require special rules. المقصور nouns often change: الدُّنْيَا → دُنْيَوِيّ (worldly), الْمَعْنَى → مَعْنَوِيّ (semantic).

title: النِّسْبَة - التَّكْوِينَات الشَّاذَّة
explanation: Some relative adjectives have irregular forms: يَد → يَدَوِيّ (manual), قَبِيلَة → قَبَلِيّ (tribal), طَبِيعَة → طَبِيعِيّ (natural), رُوح → رُوحَانِيّ (spiritual).

title: عَطْف الْبَيَان - تَعْرِيف
explanation: عطف البيان is a follower that clarifies the word before it, often a proper noun clarifying a common noun. Example: جَاءَ الْخَلِيفَةُ عُمَرُ (The caliph, Umar, came).

title: عَطْف الْبَيَان vs الْبَدَل
explanation: In البدل, the second noun can replace the first. In عطف البيان, the second only clarifies without replacing. Test: Can you remove the first word? If no → عطف البيان.

examples.english: Your brother Zaid came (Zaid can replace)

title: التَّوْكِيد اللَّفْظِيّ
explanation: التوكيد اللفظي emphasizes by repeating the exact word. Can repeat nouns, verbs, particles, or sentences: جَاءَ جَاءَ الضَّيْفُ (The guest came, came).

title: التَّوْكِيد الْمَعْنَوِيّ
explanation: التوكيد المعنوي uses specific words: نَفْس/عَيْن (self), كِلَا/كِلْتَا (both), كُلّ/جَمِيع (all). Must have a pronoun matching the emphasized word: جَاءَ الرَّجُلُ نَفْسُهُ.

title: حُرُوف الْعَطْف - الْجَمْع وَالتَّرْتِيب
explanation: وَ adds without order. فَ implies immediate sequence. ثُمَّ implies sequence with delay. حَتَّى means 'even' or 'until'.

title: حُرُوف الْعَطْف - الاخْتِيَار وَالتَّصْحِيح
explanation: أَوْ for choice/doubt. أَمْ for exclusive choice in questions. بَلْ for correction. لَكِنْ for contrast. لَا negates the second.

examples.english: Do you want tea or coffee?
This is not a pen, rather a key

title: الْبَدَل - الأَنْوَاع
explanation: Four types: بدل كل من كل (complete), بدل بعض من كل (partial), بدل اشتمال (inclusion), بدل غلط (correction). البدل takes the case of المبدل منه.

examples.english: I read the book, half of it (partial)
The student impressed me, his intelligence (inclusion)

title: الْبَدَل - الإِعْرَاب
explanation: البدل follows المبدل منه in case. Partial and inclusion types require a pronoun suffix referring back to المبدل منه: أَكَلْتُ التُّفَّاحَةَ نِصْفَهَا.

examples.english: I visited the city of Damascus
I heard the singer, his voice

title: ظَنَّ وَأَخَوَاتُهَا - أَفْعَال الشَّكّ
explanation: Verbs of doubt take two accusative objects: ظَنَّ (think), حَسِبَ (reckon), خَالَ (imagine), زَعَمَ (claim). They convert مبتدأ + خبر to مفعولين.

examples.english: They claimed he was a liar

title: ظَنَّ وَأَخَوَاتُهَا - أَفْعَال الْيَقِين وَالتَّحْوِيل
titleEn: Verbs of Thinking - Certainty and Transformation
explanation: Certainty verbs: عَلِمَ (know), رَأَى (realize), وَجَدَ (find). Transformation verbs: جَعَلَ (make), صَيَّرَ (turn into), اتَّخَذَ (take as). All take two accusatives.

examples.english: I knew honesty to be salvation
Allah made the earth a cradle

title: التَّنَازُع - التَّعْرِيف
explanation: التنازع occurs when two verbs (or verb-like words) precede a single noun, each requiring it as an object. The grammarian must decide which verb governs the shared element.

examples.english: Zaid stood and sat (both verbs 'compete' for زيد)

title: التَّنَازُع - الإِعْمَال
explanation: Basrans prefer giving governance to the second (closer) verb; Kufans prefer the first. The non-governing verb gets a pronoun referent: ضَرَبْتُهُ وَأَكْرَمْتُ زَيْدًا.

examples.english: I hit him and honored Zaid (Basran)
I hit Zaid and honored him (Kufan)
Bring me, I will pour on it molten metal (Quran)

title: الاشْتِغَال - التَّعْرِيف
explanation: الاشتغال is when a noun precedes a verb that is 'occupied' with a pronoun referring to that noun: زَيْدًا ضَرَبْتُهُ. The fronted noun is governed by a deleted verb.

title: الاشْتِغَال - أَحْكَام الإِعْرَاب
explanation: The fronted noun can be accusative (منصوب) or nominative (مرفوع as مبتدأ). Accusative is obligatory after conditional/urging particles. Nominative is obligatory after إذا الفجائية.

examples.english: If you meet Zaid, honor him (obligatory accusative)
Why didn't you fulfill the duty? (obligatory accusative)
Zaid, what an excellent man he is (obligatory nominative)

title: حَتَّى - الْجَارَّة وَالْعَاطِفَة
explanation: حتى الجارة takes a genitive noun meaning 'until': نِمْتُ حَتَّى الصَّبَاحِ. حتى العاطفة connects nouns meaning 'even': أَكَلْتُ السَّمَكَةَ حَتَّى رَأْسَهَا.

examples.english: It is peace until the emergence of dawn
I ate the fish, even its head

title: حَتَّى - النَّاصِبَة وَالابْتِدَائِيَّة
explanation: حتى الناصبة causes subjunctive meaning 'so that': سِرْتُ حَتَّى أَدْخُلَ. حتى الابتدائية introduces indicative expressing achieved result: سِرْتُ حَتَّى أَدْخُلُ.

examples.arabic: كُلُوا وَاشْرَبُوا حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَكُمُ الْخَيْطُ الْأَبْيَضُ
examples.english: Eat and drink until the white thread becomes distinct
I walked so that I may enter the city
He became so sick they had no hope for him

title: فَاء السَّبَبِيَّة - التَّعْرِيف
explanation: فاء السببية indicates cause-effect and causes the following verb to be subjunctive. There is an implied أَنْ: لَا تَكْسَلْ فَتَنْدَمَ (Don't be lazy, so you won't regret).

examples.english: Do not be lazy, so you will not regret
Study so that you may succeed
I wish I had wealth so I could spend

title: فَاء السَّبَبِيَّة - الشُّرُوط
explanation: فاء السببية requires being preceded by: negation (نفي), command (أمر), prohibition (نهي), wish (تمني), hope (رجاء), or question (استفهام).

examples.english: Do not eat too much, lest you become sick
Will you visit me so I may honor you?
Perhaps I will strive so that I may win

title: لَام الْجُحُود - التَّعْرِيف
explanation: لام الجحود intensifies negation and causes the following verb to be subjunctive. It must be preceded by negated كان: مَا كَانَ or لَمْ يَكُنْ.

title: لَام الْجُحُود vs لَام التَّعْلِيل
titleEn: Lam of Denial vs Lam of Purpose
explanation: لام الجحود requires negated كان and expresses emphatic denial. لام التعليل can appear anywhere and expresses purpose: جِئْتُ لِأَتَعَلَّمَ (I came to learn).

examples.english: I came to learn (لام التعليل - purpose)
I would never play (لام الجحود - denial)

title: كَمْ الاسْتِفْهَامِيَّة
explanation: كم الاستفهامية asks about quantity. Its تمييز (specifier) must be singular (مفرد) and accusative (منصوب): كَمْ كِتَابًا قَرَأْتَ؟

examples.english: How many books did you read?
How many days did you fast?
How many hours did you study?

title: كَمْ الْخَبَرِيَّة
explanation: كم الخبرية expresses abundance/exclamation. Its تمييز is genitive (مجرور), can be singular or plural: كَمْ كِتَابٍ قَرَأْتُ! (So many books I read!).

examples.english: So many books I have read!
How many blessings Allah has bestowed upon us!
How many towns We have destroyed (Quran)

title: صِيَغ الْمُبَالَغَة - الأَوْزَان الشَّائِعَة
explanation: صيغ المبالغة express intensity/frequency. Main patterns: فَعَّال (غَفَّار), فَعُول (صَبُور), فَعِيل (عَلِيم). Common in Allah's names.

examples.english: He is a very patient man (فَعُول)

title: صِيَغ الْمُبَالَغَة - الأَوْزَان الأُخْرَى
explanation: Additional patterns: مِفْعَال (مِقْدَام - very courageous), فَعِل (حَذِر - very cautious). These express inherent or habitual characteristics.

examples.english: He is a very courageous leader (مِفْعَال)
